Comments_List: The class had a great syllabus, and our class visits to the Beinecke to look at manuscripts were a highlight.

This was my first experience in an art history course where we focused our attention on existing scholarship rather than the art works themselves. At first, this was an adjustment, but I learned a great deal about how to analyze and discuss different scholars' interpretations of periods and works of art, emulating this careful style of analysis in my own research project.

Strengths are Professor Sullos expert hand in designing the syllabus and getting us first-hand access to the material. Weaknesses might be that it wouldve been nice to spend a little more time making explicit the connections between the units.
This course made excellent use of the art work at the YUAG and the Beinecke, which made for an immersive, interactive seminar experience.
Yes, its a great way to be approaching this period in art history.
I would if you are interested in the specific art period.
